user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_get_device_property:
```c
int metal_linux_get_device_property(struct metal_device *device,
				    const char *property_name,
				    void *output, int len)
{
	int fd = 0;
	int status = 0;
	const int flags = O_RDONLY;
	const int mode = S_IRUSR | S_IRGRP | S_IROTH;
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	char path[PATH_MAX];

	snprintf(path, sizeof(path), "%s/of_node/%s",
			 ldev->sdev->path, property_name);
	fd = open(path, flags, mode);
	if (fd < 0)
		return -errno;
	if (read(fd, output, len) < 0) {
		status = -errno;
		close(fd);
		return status;
	}

	status = close(fd);
	return status < 0 ? -errno : 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_get_device_property:
static struct linux_device *to_linux_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	return metal_container_of(device, struct linux_device, device);
}
...
struct metal_device {
	const char             *name;       /**< Device name */
	struct metal_bus       *bus;        /**< Bus that contains device */
	unsigned int           num_regions; /**< Number of I/O regions in
						 device */
	struct metal_io_region regions[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS]; /**< Array of
							I/O regions in device*/
	struct metal_list      node;       /**< Node on bus' list of devices */
	int                    irq_num;    /**< Number of IRQs per device */
	void                   *irq_info;  /**< IRQ ID */
}
...
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no fragments that modify any function parameter variable itself. Checks performed:
- device: only passed to to_linux_device(device), which returns a derived pointer; there is no assignment to the parameter device in metal_linux_get_device_property, and to_linux_device simply computes and returns the containing struct without modifying the device parameter.
- property_name: used read-only in snprintf("%s/of_node/%s", ... , property_name); there is no assignment to property_name or casts that modify it.
- output: passed to read(fd, output, len). The read call writes to the object pointed to by output, which is permitted by Rule 17.8; the pointer variable output is not reassigned anywhere in the function.
- len: only used as an argument to read and snprintf size calculations; there is no assignment to len.
- No other statements perform assignments to any of the parameter variables (device, property_name, output, len).
Therefore no code fragments in the provided function appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
